Executive Summary: 



The following provides a summary of the facility Risk Management Plan as documented in the latest RMP submission to EPA:





(a)    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Basin intends to operate the facility in a manner that prevents significant incidents or substantial threats of incidents through adherence to legal requirements, management systems, procedures and personnel training.  Basin understands the shared value of safety and environmental protection for our employees, the public and the communities we serve as a vital component of our energy infrastructure.



(b)    STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The Basin Beulah Terminal is operated by Basin Transload LLC (Basin). Rail cars of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) are stored on railroad tracks, while awaiting future transportation to another storage location or destination facility for off-load.  Once the LPG is sold, the rail cars are transported to the purchaser. LPG storage may exceed the threshold quantity.



(c) GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Basin Beulah Terminal is operated as a midstream terminal facility consisting of a truck LACT, atmospheric storage tanks, pipeline equipment and a private railroad siding used for staging and transferring liquid petroleum products to rail cars. Several additional buildings are present to support employees and terminal operations including terminal office, foreman trailer, process operation support buildings and scale shack.  

The covered process for this location is solely the storage of LPG rail cars on tracks within the private siding.  No LPG product transfer or otherwise handling except for routine rail car inspections are conducted.

-Periodic rail car inspections are conducted per an established schedule and in compliance with United States Department of Transportation (DOT) regulations.  

-While the rail cars are in the yard, Basin emp

loyees conduct periodic safety inspections of the rail cars and surrounding property.  Basin conducts, or arranges for, rail car maintenance as needed while the rail cars are on site based on inspection results or established maintenance intervals.

-Safety information has been developed for the covered process chemical, process, and equipment.

-A hazard review consisting of a Fire Safety Analysis (FSA) and hazard analysis checklist was also performed





(d) FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no accidental releases from the newly covered process that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage within the last five years.  This statement does not incorporate other processing operations at the location not under the control of Basin or any other previous site operators.



(e) EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility has developed an Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP), which has been coordinated with local emergency response groups, including the local fire department.  Basin has also contracted with a private hazardous material response contractor who is available 24-hours per day on an on-call basis.  Basin is responsible for coordinating the notifications required to initiate an emergency response. The ERAP provides the essential planning for effectively protecting the public and the environment during emergency situations.



(f) PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Compliance with Basin environmental, health, and safety standards and expectations form the framework for continuous safety improvement.  Specific actions that will be taken in the future to improve the level of safety include:

?    Compliance audits will be conducted to evaluate compliance with the CAP provisions and to evaluate improvement opportunities

?    Coordination with the local fire department will continue to ensure a constant state of readine

ss to respond to any potential emergencies

?    Additional improvements will be implemented as a result of the FSA and hazard review recommendations



Registration:

This registration includes the required information referenced in 40 CFR 68 to be reported for a Program 3 process.



Offsite Consequence Analysis:

As a Program 3 process with a regulated flammable substance, an offsite consequence analysis (OCA) has been performed for one worst-case release scenario and one alternative release scenario.  The required data from the OCA is contained within this Risk Management Plan.



Five Year Accident History:

There have been no accidental releases meeting the definition contained in 40 CFR ?68.42(a) within the last five years of operation, or in the history of the plant.



Prevention Program 3:

This Risk Management Plan includes the required information referenced in 40 CFR 68 to be reported for a Program 3 process.



Emergency Response Program:

This Emergency Response Action Plan includes the required information referenced in 40 CFR 68 to be reported for a Program 3 process.



Certification:

This submittal includes the required certification that, to the best of the signer's knowledge, information, and belief formed after reasonable inquiry, the information submitted is true, accurate, and complete.
